docs.lead_paragraph: Anthem Health, an insurer with headquarters in Piscataway, N.J., has begun discussions on a sale of its business to the United States subsidiary of a big Canadian insurer, in another illustration of the consolidation that is sweeping the health insurance industry. Executives of Anthem Health, a wholly owned subsidiary of Anthem Inc., which operates Blue Cross Blue Shield programs in several states, have been told in briefings and company memos that their organization is in talks with the Great-West Life and Annuity Insurance Company in Denver, a subsidiary of the Great-West Life Assurance Company, one of the leading health insurers in Canada, according to some of the Anthem executives.

headline.main: Anthem Health in Sale Talks With Canadian Insurer's Unit

docs.abstract: Anthem Health begins discussions on sale of its business to Great-West Life and Annuity Insurance Co, subsidiary of Great-West Life Assurance Co, in another illustration of consolidation that is sweeping health insurance industry (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE new patient in the geriatrics clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan shook Dr. Jan Maby's hand, glanced at her name badge, and submitted to all the usual questions and proddings of an initial medical examination. Only at home that evening did the patient comment acidly to the daughter who had arranged the appointment: ''So. Now you're sending me to a veterinarian?''

headline.main: Scorned No More, Osteopathy Is on the Rise

docs.abstract: Osteopathic medicine is growing in United States, and growth spurt so remarkable in today's stagnant medical climate that despite small numbers, it is beginning to attract attention among patients and health-care policy makers alike; number of osteopathic medical schools has grown to 19 from 5 in last 30 years; ranks of osteopathic practitioners, which numbered 25,000 in 1989, will reach 45,000 by 2000; osteopathic medicine has struggled for most of last 100 years to survive alongside conventional medicine with distinct philosophy but equal prerogatives; fundamental belief of osteopathy is that muscles and bones of body play more significant role in most diseases than conventional medicine allows; osteopathic medicine holds that even problems with organs deep within body--lungs, heart and brain among them--can be helped with set of hands-on technniques for sensing and correcting muscle, tendon and joint abnomalities called 'osteopathic manipulative therapy'; graph shows rise in number of osteopathic physicians (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A United Nations survey of 152 countries has found that the United States is one of only six that does not have a national policy requiring paid maternity leave. Such disparate countries as the Sudan, Cameroon, and Nepal, for example, mandate that a woman receive her salary while she is caring for her newborn. The majority of countries surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, some require the employer to pay, and still others combine both financing sources.

headline.main: U.N. Surveys Paid Leave For Mothers

docs.abstract: United Nations survey of 152 nations finds United States is one of only six that does not have national policy requiring paid maternity leave; says majority of nations surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, some require employer to pay and others combine both financing sources; finds women contribute half or more of family income in some 30 percent of households in nations studied, compared with 55 percent in United States and 59 percent in Europe (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over managed health care and consumer rights that is just beginning in Congress has been stirring a populist backlash in state capitals for several years. It is shattering historic alliances, turning doctors against doctors, doctors against business and business against otherwise pro-business Republicans. Politicians and lobbyists frame the debate as a conflict over consumer desires for good quality care and for affordable care. But they say that in the back rooms of lawmaking, the debate is only tangentially about consumers. Mostly, they say, it is about protecting the incomes, jobs and turf of the health care system's biggest and richest vested interests.

headline.main: Bills Regulating Managed Care Benefit Doctors

docs.abstract: Politicians and lobbyists say ongoing debate in state legislatures over managed health care, while framed as consumer protection battle, is mostly about protecting incomes, jobs and turf of health care system's biggest and richest vested interests; providers, mainly doctors, seem to be winning battles so far; situation in Illinois illustrates conflicts: House passed sweeping bill backed by specialist physicians that now faces dismembering in Senate, where business lobbies are stronger (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Hindu Election Prospects Cause Anxiety in India Polls in India predicted that the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, with Atal Bihari Vajpayee its candidate for prime minister, would make its strongest ever showing in national elections starting today. The possibility that the party will do well enough to form a government is causing anxiety among many Muslims and other Indians who reject Hindu nationalism as a fair basis for governing the country. A1 The death toll from bombings preceding a B.J.P. election rally in the south Indian city of Coimbatore has reached 50, the police there said. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has decided to use a one-time cash subsidy to keep down health insurance costs for some of the state's sickest people, officials said yesterday. The plan seems aimed at bolstering the Governor's record on health issues, as well as preventing an outcry over surging premiums that could bedevil his re-election campaign. In the last several weeks, two of the state's largest insurers, Oxford Health Plans and Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, have sought enormous increases for a small but costly group -- the 110,000 New Yorkers who buy health insurance on their own. These policyholders, who tend to be far sicker than average, face proposed premium increases of up to 69 percent, which could mean increases of $250 or more a month.

headline.main: PATAKI TO ASSIST HEALTH COVERAGE FOR THE INDIVIDUAL

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki, mindful that health insurance could be explosive issue in his re-election drive, proposes one-time subsidy of nearly $100 million to hold down premium rises for individuals who buy health insurance on own; these policyholders, who tend to be far sicker than average, face proposed premium increases of up to 69 percent; Pataki says he will also seek long-term solution for rapidly rising costs of individual policies; health advocates hail stand; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN her ex-husband contracted AIDS, it changed Karen Veronica's life forever. Working with his lover, she and her two teen-age daughters cared for him during the 18-month illness that kept him bed-ridden until his death in 1988. Despite the grief, there were positives that came from the experience. ''It was a hell of a year,'' Ms. Veronica said, ''but a lot of good things came out of it.''

headline.main: A Place to Feel Well Despite Toll of AIDS

docs.abstract: Bread and Roses, residential care center in Georgetown, Conn, was founded by Karen Veronica to help people with AIDS (M)1

docs.lead_paragraph: RESIDENTS of several upscale New York suburbs have acquired neighbors in recent years that many never expected -- large rental apartment buildings. A number of suburbs that had vigorously resisted multifamily housing for decades -- towns known in the apartment development industry as ''high-barrier-to-entry communities,'' zoned to protect land from unwelcome development -- are now or are soon to be the sites of apartment complexes with hundreds of rental units. And almost all the units are the work of one deep-pocketed development company, Avalon Properties, whose only business is building luxury apartments for rent.
docs.abstract: Avalon Properties is building or planning luxury rental apartment complexes in various suburban communities in New York area, including some that have resisted multifamily housing for decades; Connecticut-based company has built 15 such complexes in Fairfield and Westchester Counties, on Long Island and in New Jersey; photos; Connecticut affordable-housing law allows developers extra units if they set aside 25 percent of project for lower rentals; lawsuits brought by Avalon against Trumbull and New Canaan resulted in years of litigation, compromise and eventual victory for developer; amenities at Avalon projects described (M)
docs.snippet: RESIDENTS of several upscale New York suburbs have acquired neighbors in recent years that many never expected -- large rental apartment buildings.    A number of suburbs that had vigorously resisted multifamily housing for decades -- towns known in...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time when Dr. Charles B. Arnold had the romantic dream of leaving his job and literally sailing off into the sunset. But when he lost his job in a downsizing at Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1993, Dr. Arnold, a resident of Scarsdale, spent just a moment taking that idea seriously -- and at 59 resumed his medical training, taking a residency in psychiatry with people half his age. At 61, he was chief resident at North Shore University Hospital, and today Dr. Arnold works as a volunteer psychiatrist in the outpatient department at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Westchester Division, providing psychiatric services to the Open Arms Shelter for homeless men in White Plains at Community Center for Urban Services in Harlem. He has a small private practice as well.

headline.main: Q&A/Dr. Charles B. Arnold; When Downsizing Ends in New Horizons

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Charles B Arnold on his career shift at age 58 from public health to psychiatry after losing job in downsizing program; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislators say they are making progress on automobile insurance reform. A group of them has been holding meeting after meeting on the subject, and they have promised to submit recommendations to Governor Whitman by, well, sometime. But in case their ideas prove disappointing, the Governor has whipped up an alternate plan. She wants to spend $15 million of her new $842 million transportation budget building 200 miles of bicycle paths, including some along major highways. The bike-loving Mrs. Whitman has proposed building 2,000 miles of bicycle paths around the state over 10 years.

headline.main: Bike-Riding Governor Has a $15 Million Dream
